Risks: Stuxnet is first known software designed to interrupt operational technology. It was designed to infect networks that were not connected to the internet. Triton was first identified when used to override essential safety shut down equipment This device used could be a USB key, that is plugged into one computer to shut down the entire network. This is a risk to inventory management because housing automotives of all years/makes/models requires physical machinery that can be hacked. Link-https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/computer-science/stuxnet

Operational technology uses Internet of Things to function efficiently. Since a lot of the machinery and factories used to hold the automotive inventory are decades old, they can't receive remote updates unless owners take them offline. Doing this threatens the update of physical processes and makes it difficult for businesses to keep these assets secure. This can impact on market competitiveness and customer loyalty, financial losses, and reputational damage.

Only 20% of manufacturing companies say implementing a Secure Information and Event Management (SIEM) system is a priority. An SIEM system supports threat detection and security incident management by creating firewalls and antivirus filters. This is needed to protect the inventory and data. Link-https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/us/Documents/manufacturing/us-manufacturing-cyber-risk-in-advanced-manufacturing-executive-summary.pdf

Vehicles use Internal vehicle communication system because they vary by manufacturer, year, model. They include the CAN bus (often at high, mid, and low speeds to prioritize functionality according to the speed of messages), keyword protocol (KWP), ethernet, and others. The CAN bus is the most important because it is typically the network that transmits messages for drive-by-wire features, including steering, acceleration, and braking. The risk here is splicing through electric control units, or anything on the exterior of the vehicle such as the tire pressure monitors. Link-https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy19osti/74247.pdf
Mitigations: Manufacturers need to have all of these best practices: the ability to recognize the threat and eliminate potential vulnerabilities in the system, take inventory of all their devices and machines, segment your network enough that it allows OT and IT to work together , use vulnerability management, use of encryption in addition to security standards, access control points, proper training on computer security systems, and raising awareness, use updated software, back up data, antivirus software, securing the entire vehicleâ€™s networked functionalities with mechanical fail-safe mechanisms.

Air gapping, a security measure that isolates a computer or network and prevents it from creating an external connection, is a common approach to ICS security, when companies actually take the next step to test strategy and find fallacy. Link-https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/air-gapping

Installing a network traffic monitoring and tampering alarm in the vehicle that detects unusual CAN messages (including messages sent at unusually high rates) and transmit a warning signal to fleet managers and manufacturer cybersecurity team is a smart practice that not enough manufacturers use.

Implementing firewalls, whitelisting, and blacklisting of ECU messages to prevent unsafe commands and employing secure coding practices and auditing the source code  ensures that the right people are in control of machines and factories.

Risks: Software platforms use application programming interfaces (APIs). APIs facilitate the activation of vehicle features and delivery of subscription-based services: remote unlock, remote start, and enhanced equipment. Manufacturers need to protect APIs from malicious actors seeking access to mission-critical systems and sensitive data. Ransomware can be installed from USB port, CD/DVD port, Bluetooth, Wi-Fi at electric vehicle charging stations. Link-https://www.escrypt.com/sites/default/files/documents/Ransomware-against-cars.pdf

Cyber criminals would send TOR-based botnet such as MIREI which provides more than 400,00 bot clients. Tor allows for anonymous services that can: retrieve downloads and websites from vehicles, interpret SMS and emails within vehicles, hack into personal devices connected by bluetooth, hack into traffic infrastrucutres, and third parties such as insurance and trailers.

NIST predicts the smart grid as a future method for delivery systems, which may come with new cyber vulnerabilities. Link-https://www.nist.gov/speech-testimony/effectively-transforming-our-electric-delivery-system-smart-grid
Mitigations: When delivering these vehicles, companies should secure the complete vehicle system from the electric control unit to the cloud backend.
Manufacturing companies should complete a full testing of the vehcicle before distributing them out for any painpoints or not secure parts.

Risks: The customer support step of the supply chain is extremely important because bad actors can use ransomware or phishing to steal victimsâ€™ data. These hackers can compromise customer database and leverage details to conduct follow up attacks causing a manufacturing data breach.

Over 50% of manufacturers have mobile apps with their connected product, such as Tesla's app to control the car.  76% companies choose Wi-Fi to enable data flows between products which is highly hackable. 52% said their products are able to store/transmit confidential data including social security/banking information. More than 40% of companies don't account for these risks in their incident response plan which leaves them vulnerable for a bad actor to sell to a competing group, criminal enterprise, or nation state actor. Link-https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/us/Documents/manufacturing/us-manu-cyber-risk-in-advanced-manufacturing.pdf
Mitigations: Manufacturing companies should ensure full traceability of software versions and vehicle configuration along the vehicle lifecycle, so if there is foul play they are able to track it. Since automotive companies use a lot of external resources and services it is vital to understand everything that is coming in and out of their supply chain.
Car makers need to communicate testing results to third party car sellers to create security requirements that vendors need to follow since car data by customer is very valuable.
When providing software updates remotely, be positive that it is safe to do so by testing thoroughly and creating updates that don't impact security while sending.
